On 23/01/2008, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>  I'm currently doing some basic EJB 3.0 testing and I found that most
>  of the issues I had with the previous specification are gone. The new
>  session beans are just pojos with dependency injection and the EJB
>  stuff is merely visible as anotations.
...
>  I'm also interested in any issues people may have had with testing EJB
>  3.0 stuff, it would be nice to know what to watch out for before I'm
>  in the middle of it :)

The issue we've had with EJB3 is that the API designers completely
misunderstood dependency injection.  The container really does
*inject* dependencies, bypassing encapsulation, the constructor and
all the other language features that exist to help you manage
dependencies.

The result of this is that to unit test an session or message-driven
bean you have to duplicate the container's reflectopornographic
injection mechanism.  This is quite a bit of work.

Another downside is that you don't get any indication that you've not
provided all the dependencies to an object in a unit-test.  This makes
tests brittle.  Simple changes to an object cause a cascade of broken
tests. You can't add dependencies by using the IDEs refactoring
features to introduce new constructor parameters.  Instead you have to
annotate a field or setter method, and then manually go through
everywhere the object is used to check whether all the dependencies
have been set up correctly.

So, I still find it useful to completely decouple the business logic
from the J2EE layer.

--Nat
